utterances: And because of the positions of these two people involved - the other couple involved in this case, that they were members of his staff, either campaign or senatorial staff, apparently some ethical violations may be involved?

The Senate Ethics Committee has not decided whether to investigate yet, but obviously that's their - of course, if there's an extortion there, then there may be even more investigations going on -like from the police, shall we say.
Yeah.
But again, both Ensign and Mark Sanford are mentioned as possible Republican presidential candidates 2012.
By the way, Haley Barbour begins his tour of Iowa and New Hampshire today.
The current governor of Mississippi.
Of Mississippi.
But for the most part, it's not been a good week for Republicans.
Let's also talk about a week in Albany that has been good for neither Republicans or Democrats.
The comedy of the New York State Senate gets funnier and funnier.

Now it's obviously no comity with a T, a lot D, comedy, and what happened yesterday, this New York State Senate is split 31-31, and so both the Democrats and Republicans showed up yesterday at a session, and the Democrats actually snuck in earlier than expected, and what they did was they turned off the - they were in charge of the audio and video equipment.

They turned off the microphones and the video whenever the Republicans were talking, and basically both the 31 Republicans and 31 Democrats were talking at each other and yelling at each other, and it was like - it was a food fight.

This is, of course, a special session called by the governor, David Paterson, to pass critical legislation that has to be passed before the end of the month or special authorities for places like New York City run out, and they're - it's nice to know that sixth grade goes on forever.

I mean, we laugh, and we roll our eyes on this, but as you say, this is serious legislation that is not getting passed, and it's not helping David Paterson's chances of getting re-elected next year - or at least elected, because he became governor when another governor got involved in some problems, like Eliot Spitzer and prostitution.
So it's been a very weird bunch of months for governors on both sides of the aisle.
And a correction.
Richard Russell was from Georgia.
I misidentified the state as Louisiana.
I apologize.
But he's still dead.

He's still dead, still from Heaven at that point, and going on to the Senate race in Illinois, Roland Burris, another accidental senator in this case, well there's some thought that he may not only hang on to his Senate seat - there was some doubt about that for awhile - but may decide to run for election on his own.
Well, he might do that.
Of course, they said they are not - the state legislature, which was looking into his activities, ultimately said that they will not investigate any accusations of perjury.
Vagueness is not the same as lying.
Right, about his relationship with the former governor, Blagojevich.
And there's some thought about somebody who may run against him, as well.
Well, there are a lot of people who are going to run against him.
Who are you thinking of?
I was thinking about the White House, talking about a female candidate.
Oh that's right, Lisa Madigan, the state attorney general.
I'm sorry, I didn't read your lips.
Attorney General Lisa Madigan, who had been looking at a run for governor for a long time.
Of course, she was thinking of running against Rod Blagojevich when Blagojevich was such an easy target.

Now that's gone, and Pat Quinn is the new governor of Illinois, the White House would love to keep Quinn, who just so happens is a - works with David Axelrod, the client of David Axelrod, but also they think that Lisa Madigan would be a stronger Senate candidate.
Ken Rudin, our political junkie, is with us, as he is is every Wednesday.

This is TALK OF THE NATION.

It's Wednesday, Political Junkie day.
Ken Rudin joins us, as always.
He's NPR's political editor.
If you don't hear him on the radio, he's probably updating his blog.
You can check that out at npr.org/junkie.
Any Richard Russell updates?
Yesterday, one of things Ken wrote about was President Obama's news conference at the White House.
Many of those watching noticed a change in tone between reporters and the president.
There were some tough questions.
Obviously, these events are not open to the public, so we want to take you behind the scenes in the Brady Briefing Room and speak with a veteran White House correspondent.
What do you want to know about how a presidential press briefing works?
Who gets to ask questions and why?
Our phone number is 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And joining us now from the White House is NPR White House correspondent Don Gonyea.
Hey, Don.
Hey, glad to be here.
And you've covered your share of presidential news conferences.
So first question, Mr. White House correspondent, why did yesterday's news conference move from the Rose Garden on a beautiful summer's day into the Brady Briefing Room?
It just seems curious to me.
I mean, what a beautiful backdrop that would have been.
There is no official answer, but I am told there were concerns about the heat.

It was going to get well into the 90s - or 80s, 80s anyway, yesterday here in a District of Columbia June, and it was pretty humid, and I don't for a minute think they were worried that we reporters would be swearing and uncomfortable and suffering from dehydration and everything else.
I think there might have been concerns that it just doesn't look good to have a president taking questions on difficult topics and have him be covered in sweat from the humidity.
I think maybe they were just worried that more flies might attack him.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But anyway, the - let me ask you a question.
The president made his opening statement.
He talked about Iran, he talked about the energy bill, he talked about health care.
His first question, as might be expected, was on Iran.
And now we're going to play a cut of tape from yesterday's news conference, and this is what the president had to say after he finished answering that first question on Iran.
Since we're on Iran, I know Nico Pitney is here from Huffington Post.
Thank you, Mr. President.
Nico, I know there's you and all across the Internet, we've been seeing a lot of reports coming directly out of Iran.
I know that there may actually be questions from people in Iran who are communicating through the Internet.
Do you have a question?
Yeah, I just - I wanted to use this opportunity to ask you a question directly from an Iranian.
And there's two questions about that, Don Gonyea.
Clearly this was a setup.
The president knew this question was out there.
And he tipped his hand.
Now, he didn't quite tell us how much of a setup it was.

He did reveal that he knew Nico Pitney from the Huffington Post was out there and that he had a question on a certain topic, even if we didn't know what the specific question - he didn't know what the specific question would be.
But yes, it was a setup.
What we later learned was that the White House had seen the blog postings that Mr. Pitney had been doing and actually invited him to come, which is unusual.
And another question.
So White House correspondents get to ask questions, and so do Iranian bloggers?
Well that is the interesting thing here.

You know, typically - and again, this administration has thrown a lot of the, you know, usual - I won't call them rules, but let's just call them kind of standard routine, protocol, whatever, out the window.

But it is interesting to kind of seek out a question not even from a reporter but from, you know, someone in Iran, which is what Mr. Pitney was doing, passing along questions he had gotten through his own Web postings, which isn't to say that there aren't, you know, there aren't plenty of ways that the president could entertain such questions and could arrange to do so.
But it was unusual having it come up within a briefing room where a presidential press conference is taking place.
Ken?

Don, clearly the president seemed to welcome or expect the question from the Huffington Post questioner, but he seemed a little testy, I thought, with some questions about Iran from the guy from Fox News who asked him, what took you so long; from the CBS news reporter who said that - did you become tough becauseâ€¦
